Name: Texas (USA)
Description: No meaningful cap for payday-style lenders; reported average of 662% APR for some short-term lenders. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

Name: Wisconsin (USA)
Description: Very high allowable rates for certain payday or title lenders (no strict cap). :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

Name: Michigan (USA)
Description: Caps for payday-loan-type products are around 400% APR according to user-reported data. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}

Name: Idaho (USA)
Description: Limited cap / very high rates allowed per some sources; unconscionability standard applies. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

Name: US Military Lending Act (USA)
Description: Federal cap for certain consumer credit products under the Military Lending Act. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}

Name: Poland (EU)
Description: Under Poland’s Anti-Usury Act (2024), stricter annual percentage rate limits are introduced. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

Name: France (EU)
Description: For certain consumer credit / revolving credit, official ceiling around 20% for high-cost credit. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

Name: Italy (EU)
Description: Italian ‘usury’ threshold law — interest rates cannot exceed ~50% of bank APR per older usury legislation. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

Name: Japan (National)
Description: Tiered caps: 20% for small loans, 15% for large loans.

Name: Philippines (National)
Description: Philippines suspended ceilings, but regulators can impose limits.

Name: Singapore
Description: capped at 4% per month on overdue amounts.This translates to about 48% APR if compounded annually.

Name: Switzerland
Description: Swiss Consumer Credit Act: max interest = SARON + 10%. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}

Name: Australia (National)
Description: Under the National Consumer Credit Protection Act (Australia), a 48% p.a. cap (inclusive of fees) applies to many consumer credit contracts. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}

Name: Tonga (Pacific)
Description: Typical commercial lending margins in Tonga are ~6% to 11% over base, based on a comparative report. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}

Name: Spain (EU)
Description: its Usury Law (1908) voids loans with interest `notably higher than normal` or `manifestly disproportionate,` with Spanish courts using the Bank of Spain's average rates (TIN/TAE) as benchmarks, generally finding rates significantly above the average (e.g., 6 percentage points or more) in revolving credit and consumer loans as usurious, making around 20% APR

Name: Solomon Islands (Pacific)
Description: Reported typical interest margin for commercial bank loans is ~11%. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
